üëç
I agree that `-1` is a more sensible default especially when running an untuned producer on Linux over a long fat network instead of the default 128 KiB for `send.buffer.bytes`.

I believe the default `net.core.wmem_max` is often set to 256 KiB preventing the `SO_SNDBUF` to be really set to something higher than 256 KiB (technically it will be bound to 512 KiB as the Linux kernel double the size internally).
On the other hand, from what I have seen if you do not set `SO_SNDBUF` (with `send.buffer.bytes` set to `-1`) then you are not bound by `net.core.wmem_max` anymore but by `net.ipv[46].tcp_wmem` which is often set to a 4 MiB max size that tremendously increase throughput on high latency network (obviously after configuring lingering and batching accordingly).

My current workaround consists of setting `net.core.wmem_max` to match the max of `net.ipv[46].tcp_wmem` and only then I can really use `send.buffer.bytes` with something bigger than 256 KiB.

I found that using `-1` allows to get better performance out of the box on Linux while allowing system engineers to do some TCP tuning with or without configuring the application.

The same applies to `SO_RCVBUF` although it is probably less common to run a consumer over a long fat network.

According to the profile I managed to dig up, posted here https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3811 I believe the root cause of most of the CPU time is probably waiting for the lock on the sensor object here:

https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/common/metrics/Sensor.java#L100

A little bit of time is spent on time.milliseconds() calls, and I'd imagine avoiding the metrics record of polling when no records are processed is probably helpful, but from that profile it looks like most of the time is spent inside of the Sensor.record() method itself -- what would explain that to me is if there is a ton of contention on locking the Sensor object, and if I had to guess it's during the call here during processing of each record:

https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/streams/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/processor/internals/StreamThread.java#L323

I don't understand the wider code well enough to say where the contention is coming from. If it's possible to either reduce the size of the critical section, lower the granularity of the lock, etc, I'd imagine that'd be the biggest win.
I did base the unit tests code on existing style from the neighbor tests but I changed it to `@Test(expected = ...)` that's more concise if we do not care about the exception message validation.
LGTM.
Thanks, LGTM.

@gfodor The same metrics object are used across all threads within a KafkaStreams instance, and since the sensors are created with the same sensor name, they are technically shared among all the threads as well. So with multiple threads it could cause contention. How many threads are you using per-instance in your profiling experiment?

Okay since the overhead seems not mainly from `time.nanoseconds`, I will change it back from `milliseconds` as it provides more accurate metrics. And I will probably leave the other optimizations in this ticket.

Two open questions I'd like to hear everyone's opinions @enothereska @mjsax @dguy @junrao @ijuma @jkreps regarding to further optimize metrics recording in Kafka Streams:
1. Before Streams we usually only have one thread per each client (think of producer and consumer), and hence no contention will ever happen. For Kafka Streams we have configurable number of background threads, but originally I still want to keep the metric sensors to be at the per-instance level instead of per-thread level, since the latter case may be cumbersome for users to monitor and alert on. However we will incur concurrent contention on the shared sensor objects. 

So should we consider 1) removing the `synchronized` block on the Sensor, and just making sure that there will be no concurrent access modifying the same data structure (think of `add` and `record` calls), or 2) fall back to per-thread metrics reporting, or 3) just bite the bullet of contention for per-instance metrics reporting.
1. An semi-related question is, whether or not we should record metrics on each record. Remember in other clients since we do batching on request / responses, we are batching on metrics recording naturally. For Kafka Streams where we do one-record-at-a-time, should we consider 1) sampling on metrics recording (i.e. only record per every x records), or 2) batching and taking average metrics (i.e. accumulate values every x records, and record only once taking the average). Both will reduce the overhead of calling `time`, and also possible contentions if we go with option 3) above, with the trade-off that we may be missing outliers as we are recording, for example, "min / max of averages".

@guozhangwang KAFKA-3115 is related. I think the right solution for an issue like this would be to collect per thread metrics and then aggregate them periodically (ignoring sampling for now). Even without a lock, the cache effects of mutating shared variables often from multiple threads won't be pretty.

Before spending a lot of time on this, it's probably a good idea to verify what is the best case scenario we can achieve without sampling. We could first switch to per thread metrics and measure the impact. And we could then remove synchronization from `Sensor` (even though it makes it thread unsafe) and measure again. Adding per-instance aggregated metrics and some form of thread-safety would introduce some overhead, so the above would give us an idea if this is good enough or if we need to go down the sampling route.

Regarding sampling:  Another thing we should consider is that, by doing sampling, we might miss (say) latency outliers, so e.g. 99% percentiles might suddenly appear better than they actually are?
Build failure seems to be an instance of KAFKA-3155.
LGTM. I'll let @guozhangwang review it too since he reviewed the original PR.
LGTM. I think the test case covers both changes.

Per thread metrics and removal of synchronization on `Sensor`. Metric collection should be as low overhead as possible, so we don't want to be introducing contention, locks etc. Also, users can also aggregate the per thread metrics if we don't do it. In some respects it is much better to get the raw values rather than averages of averages of averages.

As for the last point regarding batching, i don't really like it. I see the point of reducing the overhead, but we now have an average, that will be rolled up into another average. Data points are lost. But i get there is likely a tradeoff here
LGTM. Merged to trunk.

Did you test MM after these changes? Based on visual inspection I had one small comment, otherwise it LGTM.
Yeah, I'm also a little puzzled why this is needed.

Hey Grant/ Jason, thanks for the quick review. If you have a pipeline where data arrives say every few minutes, polling every second seems to be extraneous. Having that said, increasing poll time is not going to save lots of CPU cycles, so it is up for debate if this is worth a new config or not. In old consumer one would have controlled this using `consumer.timeout.ms` and adding this config will allow users to set the poll time for new consumers as well.

@SinghAsDev Hey Ashish, to be honest, I'm not sure why we're using 1 second as the poll timeout. Would there be any downside to just increasing it? From a glance at the code, it seems like we catch the exception and retry anyway. Also, one iteration of the loop per second seems like it would have minimal impact on CPU.

@hachikuji increasing timeout seems to be reasonable. If someone is getting high speed data then they do not have worry about the timeout anyway. However, that again raises the question what is an optimal value for timeout, IMO it depends on incoming data speed. What do you think is a good default value?

I would probably use `Long.MAX_VALUE`. We break from poll() as soon as any data is available, so there's no obvious downside to blocking in poll() when there's nothing available. Unless maybe we depend on the timeouts to trigger some periodic behavior?
I do not see any behavior depending on `ConsumerTimeoutException` in MirrorMaker, it just gets trace logged. @becketqin would have any suggestion on this?

It seems to me that only about 3% of the CPU time in my profile was spent actually doing work below the Sensor.record call -- which isn't great but is certainly tolerable for metrics. So, if it turns out the lock is where the rest of the time is coming from, eliminating the lock safely probably would be a sufficient fix.

Thanks @mangas, LGTM. Ran the tests locally and they passed.

For reference, I'll mention here that @fpj said that the upgrade sounded fine in the original PR https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1504#issuecomment-226109213 .

Merged to trunk.

@ijuma I had looked to see if there were unit tests around this area, but couldn't find any. Producer good path gets tested in integration tests, but it looks difficult to add a test for the failure in this JIRA without refactoring the producer implementation to make it easier to inject failures.

About batching: we can still do an exact computation if we not do average-over-average, but update sum-of-time-spent and number-of-records (both values updated in batches). If anybody request the metric, we just compute the average on demand.

I also agree, that a per-thread metric would be a good choice to get rid of the lock. To improve user experience, I like the idea to compute overall metric over all threads under the hood. Not sure if fine-grained metric access per thread helps the user, because the user does not know which part of the data each thread processes (or is this information available?). Thus, I would vote for per-thread metric collection plus global reporting.

What I do not understand: why should timeMillis be more precises than timeNano?
@ijuma thanks for your help, how soon is the next release?

@ijuma I think we can get to a better balance. We already include IDE-specific files, and I think extending that to any files commonly left by editors, file browsers, etc makes sense, but we can still cut down the current version a lot by removing stuff that really has no business being in a Kafka checkout in the first place. I think we can cut another ~50% of the remaining additions to get something that isn't too bloated.
